title: 10. The Follicular Phase of the Ovarian Cycle II

vectorData.altText: H12   The Follicular Phase of the Ovarian Cycle II

Secondary (Antral) Follicles
Granulosa cells secrete follicular fluid, which accumulates in the extracellular space and forces the cells apart. As the fluid accumulates, the spaces coalesce, forming an antrum. Follicular fluid contains many factors, including steroids, growth factors, and anticoagulants.
Mature (Graafian) Follicle
A mature follicle may be 2 cm or more in diameter, and is visible on ultrasound. The oocyte is surrounded by a halo of granulosa cells, the corona radiata    , which will accompany it upon ovulation. The corona radiata is attached to the follicular wall by granulosa cells termed the cumulus     oophorus. The development of a mature follicle from a primordial follicle takes about 90 days.
Many Develop, but Only One Survives     (usually)
Each month, many primordial follicles are stimulated to begin the process described. Of these, usually only one becomes a mature follicle, and a single oocyte is released at ovulation. The remaining follicles degenerate through atresia at various stages. They do, however, play a significant role, in that the estrogens they produce contribute to the rise in circulating estrogen levels that occurs during the follicular phase of the ovarian cycle, and which stimulates the reproductive tract to transport and nourish the embryo, should fertilization occur.
Remember, a primordial follicle consists of a 1° oocyte (halted in the prophase of the first meiotic division), surrounded by a single layer of flattened follicular cells.
narrated by Morgan Freeman or David Attenborough, of course.
That could be the title of a nature documentary!

This histological image of the ovary shows a Secondary Follicle within the cortex.

Remember, at this time the follicle still contains a primary oocyte halted in meiosis I. The oocyte itself is surrounded by a few layers of granulosa cells referred to as the corona radiata (CR). The granulosa cells that anchor the corona radiata to the follicular wall is referred to as the cumulus oophorus (CO). These structures, together with the fluid-filled antrum allow one to distinguish a secondary follicle from a primary follicle.

Also identified in this image are the theca interna (TI) and theca externa (TE). Around the time the secondary follicle is maturing, the surrounding theca differentiate into two layers. The theca interna is the internal layer which secretes steroids. The theca externa is the outermost layer of the theca composed of fibroblasts and a few other cell types.

This histological image of the ovary shows a Graafian Follicle. A Graafian follicle can be distinguished from a secondary follicle by its size. Also, the Graafian follicle has a larger fluid-filled antrum. In this follicle, the oocyte is not entirely in the plane of section and so the nucleus is not seen.
